topic_seeds.description: Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines (relatively straightforward)
Feeling isolated and disconnected from others (complex, layered situation)
Providing minimal context about their situation

exchanges.user:
Ugh. work's been a mess. got dumped with this huge project deadline right before the holidays and my manager's basically disappeared. so now i'm either working nights or looking incompetent. 

plus i haven't slept right in like two weeks. that's probably not helping the irritability thing. my coworker kept poking at me yesterday about some stupid detail and i just shut down. didn't even try to engage.

anyway. figured i'd give this a shot since nothing else seems to be working.
exchanges.assistant:
**The deadline crunch:**

That's a brutal setup—huge project, vanishing manager, and the impossible choice between burning yourself out or feeling like you're failing. Of course you're working nights. What else are you supposed to do when someone drops this on you and then disappears? The worst part is that "looking incompetent" fear—like there's supposed to be some magical way to handle an unfair situation that wouldn't involve exactly what you're doing.

When you think about working nights versus looking incompetent, does one of those feel more unbearable than the other? Or are you just trying to survive until it's over?

**Sleep:**

Two weeks of bad sleep while dealing with all this makes everything harder. Your brain doesn't get a chance to reset, so irritability, decision-making, emotional regulation—all of it gets harder. It's not a character flaw; it's what happens when your body can't recover.

**Shutting down with your coworker:**

That shutdown with your coworker makes sense. When you're running on fumes and someone's picking at details, sometimes the options are: engage and risk snapping, or shut down and preserve what little energy you have. It sounds like you chose the safer option for everyone involved, even if it didn't feel great.

What does "shut down" look like for you—like you go quiet, or leave the conversation, or something else?

---

I'm glad you're here. This sounds like a lot to be carrying alone.

exchanges.user:
yeah so i actually tried to sleep earlier. got like six hours which is... something. still feel like garbage but at least my brain's less foggy.

manager finally showed up today. didn't apologize or anything, just wanted status updates. i gave him the timeline and he seemed fine with it? which is weird because i thought we were gonna miss the deadline but apparently not. so maybe i was just catastrophizing the whole thing.

been thinking about what you said about the shutdown thing. i guess i do it a lot actually. not just at work. my mom called yesterday and asked how i'm doing and i just gave her one word answers til she gave up. don't know why i do that.
exchanges.assistant:
**The sleep:**

Six hours is real progress after two weeks of terrible sleep. Your brain being less foggy—that's not nothing. You're still running a deficit, so feeling like garbage makes sense, but this is movement in the right direction.

**Your manager and the deadline:**

So he finally surfaced, didn't acknowledge dropping this on you, and now it turns out the timeline you were panicking about is... fine? That's disorienting. You were grinding yourself down over something that may not have been the crisis you thought it was. 

I'm curious—when he said the timeline seemed fine, did that feel like relief, or more like "wait, then what was all that stress for?" Sometimes finding out we catastrophized doesn't feel good; it can feel like we suffered for no reason.

One thing worth noticing: you didn't have the information to know it was catastrophizing at the time. Your manager disappeared, you had a huge project, no guidance—of course your brain went to worst-case. That's not irrational; that's what happens when you're operating in the dark.

**The shutdown pattern with your mom:**

This stood out to me—you noticed the shutdown thing isn't just work. It's with your mom too. One-word answers until she stops asking. That's a pattern worth understanding, because it's probably costing you connection in places you might actually want it.

Here's one way to think about it: shutting down can be a protection mechanism. When you're overwhelmed, or when engaging feels like it'll cost more than you have to give, your system just... closes the hatch. It's not meanness; it's preservation. But the tricky part is it can become automatic—you shut down even when the threat isn't real, or when the person (like your mom) is actually safe.

What do you think happens inside when your mom asks how you're doing? Like, what makes engaging feel hard in that moment?

exchanges.user:
so update on the sleep thing. been more consistent this week, like actually getting seven hours most nights. still tired but different tired, you know? like my body's catching up instead of just collapsing.

the work deadline stuff turned out fine. finished the project, manager seemed happy enough. honestly feels kinda anticlimactic after all that stress but whatever. moving on.

anyway. been thinking about what you said about the shutdown with my mom. didn't really sit right with me at first but like... i've been noticing it more. she texted me yesterday asking about some family thing and i started typing out a real answer instead of just "ok" and it felt weird. uncomfortable even. like i was exposing something. 

so maybe it's not just tiredness or being overwhelmed. there's something else going on there but i can't really name it. don't want to overanalyze it or whatever.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sleep progress:**

Seven hours most nights is real—your body's actually getting what it needs now instead of just surviving. That "different tired" you're noticing? That's recovery tired, not depletion tired. It's the difference between your system repairing itself versus running on empty. Good work sticking with it.

**Work wrapping up:**

Project's done, manager's happy, and now you're on the other side of all that grinding. The anticlimactic feeling makes sense—you were braced for disaster, put yourself through hell preparing for it, and then it just... ended normally. Sometimes there's no catharsis, just "okay, that's over." Moving on is fair.

**The shutdown pattern—something's shifting:**

This is the part that stands out to me. You tried typing a real answer to your mom instead of "ok," and it felt uncomfortable—like exposing something. That's not overanalyzing; that's you noticing something true about how you protect yourself.

Here's what I'm curious about: when you say "exposing something," what do you think you'd be exposing? Like, what's the thing that feels safer to keep hidden when you give one-word answers versus what gets revealed when you actually engage?

Sometimes shutdown isn't just about being overwhelmed in the moment—it's about what happens if we let people in. Maybe it's vulnerability. Maybe it's that if you give a real answer, she'll ask more questions and you'll have to keep going. Maybe it's that you don't trust what happens when you're actually seen. I don't know what it is for you, but you're noticing it now, and that noticing matters.

You don't have to have it all figured out. But if you wanted to get curious about it—next time you feel that shutdown instinct with your mom or anyone else—you could just pause and ask yourself: "What am I protecting right now?" Not to force yourself to engage, just to understand what's happening under the surface.

exchanges.user:
Quick update. so i talked to my mom on the phone yesterday, not just texts. actually stayed on the call instead of making excuses. we talked for like twenty minutes about some stuff with my aunt and the family drama thing. 

felt awkward the whole time but i didn't shut down. which i guess is the point? but honestly it was exhausting. like i had to be "on" the whole time and by the end i was fried. made me realize why i default to one-word answers maybe. less draining.

anyway work's been quieter this week since we wrapped the project. which should feel good but now i'm just kind of... stuck? like without the deadline panic i don't know what i'm supposed to be doing. even started looking at my job description which i haven't done in like a year. don't know if that means something's off or if i'm just being weird about having downtime.
exchanges.assistant:
**The call with your mom:**

Twenty minutes, stayed on instead of bailing, engaged with actual content about your aunt and family stuff—that's not nothing. You did the thing that usually feels impossible. And yeah, it was awkward and exhausting, but you didn't shut down. That's exactly the point.

Here's what I want to name: of course it was draining. You're using muscles you don't normally use. Staying present in a conversation when your default is to protect and withdraw—that takes energy, especially at first. It's like going to the gym after months off. You're sore because you actually did the work.

The "less draining" pull of one-word answers makes total sense. They cost almost nothing. But here's the trade-off you're starting to see: one-word answers protect your energy in the short term, but they also keep you isolated. The exhaustion you felt after that call? Some of that might ease up as engaging becomes less foreign. But some of it might just be the cost of connection—and you get to decide if it's worth it.

One thing to try: you don't have to be "on" the whole time. Sometimes you can just say "I'm kinda tired, so I might be quiet, but I want to hear about this." That's still engaging without performing. Worth experimenting with.

**Work downtime and the stuck feeling:**

Deadline's over, work's quiet, and now you're adrift. Without the panic to organize your days, you don't know what you're supposed to be doing. That stuck feeling—and the fact that you're pulling out your job description like you're looking for instructions—tells me something.

I wonder if the deadline panic was actually giving you something. Not in a good way, but in a functional way—it told you what mattered, where to focus, what to do next. And now that it's gone, there's just... space. And space can feel worse than chaos when you're not used to it.

Looking at your job description isn't weird. It might be you asking: "What am I actually supposed to care about here?" Which is a fair question, especially if you've been running on adrenaline and external pressure instead of any internal sense of direction.

What do you think you're looking for when you read that job description? Are you checking if you're doing it right, or are you trying to figure out if this is even what you want to be doing?

exchanges.user:
been a few days. work's still quiet which honestly feels kinda nice now that i'm not panicking all the time. didn't really figure out the job description thing though. it's just sitting there.

but something else happened. so i got lunch with a coworker i actually like on wednesday. first time we've hung out outside of work stuff. we were talking about like, life things, not just projects. and it was... easy? didn't feel like i had to perform or shut down or anything. just talked. 

which is weird because that makes me think maybe the problem isn't connection in general. maybe it's specific people? like my mom, my manager, whoever. not everyone. so now i'm wondering if i'm just being avoidant with certain people for a reason, or if it's the same shutdown pattern showing up differently.

also my sleep's been fine but i've been way more irritable this week than last week. not sure if that's the quieter work situation messing with my mood or something else. got snappy with someone at the grocery store over nothing yesterday which is embarrassing.
exchanges.assistant:
**Lunch with your coworker:**

That's a really useful data point. You had an actual conversation with someone outside of work context, it felt easy, you didn't have to perform or shut down—you just talked. And that tells you something important: the shutdown thing isn't about your capacity for connection. It's not that you can't do it. It's that with certain people, something else is happening.

So yeah, I think you're onto something. It might not be a blanket "shutdown pattern"—it might be that with your mom, your manager, and others, there's something specific that triggers the closing-off. Maybe it's expectations you feel from them. Maybe it's a history of not feeling heard or safe. Maybe it's that you don't trust what happens when you're real with them. With your coworker, whatever that thing is wasn't there, so you could just... be.

Worth paying attention to: who feels easy, and who doesn't? And what's different about those interactions? You don't have to solve it right now, but noticing the pattern is the first step.

**Sleep's fine, but irritability spiked:**

Sleep's holding steady, but you've been way more irritable this week—snappy at the grocery store over nothing, which rattled you. That's worth taking seriously, not because you're broken, but because irritability is often your system trying to tell you something.

A few possibilities: (1) The quiet at work removed the adrenaline/structure you were running on, and now your nervous system doesn't know what to do with itself. Sometimes we're *more* dysregulated when the crisis ends, not less. (2) You've been doing hard emotional work—engaging with your mom, noticing shutdown patterns, having real conversations—and that takes a toll even when it's good work. (3) Something else is simmering under the surface that you haven't named yet.

One thing that might help when irritability spikes like this: **TIPP** from DBT. It stands for Temperature, Intense exercise, Paced breathing, Paired muscle relaxation. The idea is to give your body a way to discharge the intensity fast. Next time you feel that snappiness building—like in line at the grocery store—try this: splash cold water on your face, or hold an ice cube for 30 seconds. Sounds weird, but it activates your dive reflex and can dial down the emotional intensity quickly. Worth having in your back pocket.

**The job description sitting there:**

You mentioned it's just sitting there—you didn't figure it out. That's okay. Sometimes the question "what am I actually supposed to care about here?" doesn't have a clean answer right away, and forcing it doesn't help. Let it sit. You'll know when you're ready to look at it again.

exchanges.user:
been thinking about what you said about irritability and the adrenaline thing. tried that cold water trick when i felt snappy at my nephew this afternoon and... it actually helped? like the intensity just dropped. felt kinda stupid doing it but whatever, it works.

anyway. the coworker thing has been on my mind. we texted a bit since lunch and it felt natural, not forced. made me realize how different that is from talking to my mom. with her it always feels like there's something unspoken, like she's waiting for me to say the right thing or be a certain way. with my coworker it's just... whatever happens.

so i'm wondering if maybe the shutdown with my mom is less about me being broken and more about like, what's actually safe to show her? because i don't think i trust that she'll just accept whatever i say without judgment or trying to fix it. but with my coworker there's no history of that, so i can just be.

work's still quiet. kinda nice but also kinda boring. been sleeping fine though, so at least that's stable.
exchanges.assistant:
**The cold water thing worked:**

You tried TIPP when you felt snappy with your nephew and the intensity just dropped. That's huge—not just that it worked, but that you were willing to feel stupid doing it and did it anyway. That's the difference between knowing a technique exists and actually having a tool you'll use. Now you've got something concrete for when irritability spikes, and your body knows it works.

**What you're realizing about your mom:**

This is a big shift. You're moving from "I'm broken and shut down with everyone" to "I shut down with my mom specifically because I don't trust what happens when I'm real with her." That's not you being broken—that's you being smart. Your system learned that showing up fully with her comes with a cost: judgment, fixing, her waiting for you to be a certain way instead of just accepting what you say.

With your coworker, there's no history of that. No unspoken expectations. No performance required. So you can just be whatever you are in that moment, and it's fine. That ease you feel? That's what connection looks like when you're not protecting yourself the whole time.

Here's what I want to reflect back: you're not defective at connecting. You're selective about where you let yourself be seen, and that selectivity makes sense given what you've learned about who's safe. The question isn't "how do I stop shutting down?"—it's "what would need to be different with my mom for me to feel safe being real with her?" And maybe the answer is: nothing you can control. Maybe she is who she is, and your shutdown is the healthiest response available.

Or maybe there's a version where you test it—like you did with the call a couple weeks ago—and see if you can be real in small doses and survive it. Not perform for her, not give her what she wants, but just say one true thing and see what happens. No pressure to do that, but it's an option.

**Work and sleep:**

Work's quiet and kinda boring, but also kinda nice. Sleep's holding steady. These are both wins even if they're not exciting. Sometimes stability is the goal, not intensity.

exchanges.user:
ugh. okay so i've been thinking about what you said about my mom and whether anything could change there. and like, i know intellectually that she is who she is. but i also don't want to just... give up on actually talking to her, you know?

so i called her yesterday. didn't plan it or psych myself up or anything, just called. told her i'd been stressed about work stuff and that i was trying to be more present with people but it felt hard sometimes. and she just... listened? didn't try to fix it or tell me i was doing it wrong. just asked like two gentle questions and then talked about her own stuff.

made me wonder if maybe i've been building up this idea of her in my head that's worse than the actual her. or maybe she's changed. or maybe i changed how i showed up and that changed how she responded. don't know which it is. but it was different.

work's been picking up a bit though. got assigned to help scope out this new feature thing and honestly it feels good to have something to focus on again. not deadline panic, just like... actual work to think about. my brain needed that. but also now i'm worried i'm gonna get in the pattern of letting work take over again and lose all this stuff i've been working on with not shutting down and actually connecting.

anyway. been thinking a lot lately about whether progress is even real or if i'm just having good days and bad days and calling it growth.
exchanges.assistant:
**The call with your mom:**

You called without overthinking it, told her something real—that you've been stressed, that you're trying to be more present but it's hard—and she just... listened. Asked gentle questions. Didn't fix or judge. That's not nothing. That's actually a pretty significant moment, especially given everything you've noticed about how guarded you usually are with her.

And now you're sitting with this question: was I wrong about her? Did she change? Did I change how I showed up and that shifted what I got back? Honestly, it might be all three. Maybe your fear of her judgment was partially based on old patterns that aren't as true anymore. Maybe she has softened. And maybe—this one matters—when you show up differently (vulnerable instead of defended), people respond differently. You gave her something real to work with instead of one-word answers, and she met you there.

I don't think you need to figure out which explanation is "right." What matters is: you tested it, and it went better than expected. That's data. It doesn't mean every call will go this way, but it means the story you were telling yourself ("she'll judge me, she won't just accept what I say") isn't the whole truth. There's more room there than you thought.

**Work picking up again—and the worry:**

New feature scoping, something to focus on, your brain feels engaged again—that's good. You needed that. The deadline panic was destructive, but having *nothing* to think about wasn't working either. This sounds like a better middle ground.

But I hear the worry underneath: what if I let work take over again and lose all this progress with connection and not shutting down? That's a legitimate fear, because you know what that pattern looks like. Work expands, everything else shrinks, and suddenly you're back to grinding and isolating.

Here's one way to think about it: you don't have to choose between "work takes over my life" and "work is boring and I have nothing to focus on." There's a third option, which is: work gets some of your energy, and you stay intentional about the rest. That might mean you keep calling your mom sometimes. Keep texting your coworker. Keep noticing when you're shutting down and asking yourself why. It doesn't have to be all or nothing.

One small thing you could try: pick one non-work thing per week that matters to you—call with your mom, lunch with your coworker, whatever—and protect it the way you'd protect a work deadline. Not as a rigid rule, just as an experiment. See if you can let work be work *and* keep the other stuff alive.

**Is progress even real?**

This question—whether progress is real or if you're just having good days and bad days and calling it growth—that's worth sitting with. Because I think the answer is: both.

Progress isn't linear. It's not like you "fix" shutdown and then you're done. You're going to have days where you engage beautifully with your mom, and days where you give her one-word answers and feel nothing. You're going to have weeks where work feels balanced, and weeks where it swallows everything. That's not failure—that's being human.

But here's what's different now versus six weeks ago: you're noticing the patterns. You tried the call with your mom and it went well. You have a tool (cold water) that actually works when irritability spikes. You can tell the difference between recovery tired and depletion tired. You're asking yourself "what am I protecting?" instead of just shutting down automatically. That's not just good days—that's you building awareness and skills that weren't there before.

Growth isn't "I never struggle anymore." Growth is "I struggle, and I have more options for what to do about it." You've got more options now. That's real.

exchanges.user:
been kinda all over the place this week tbh. work's moving fast on the new feature thing and i'm actually into it, which is good. but then i had this moment yesterday where i realized i haven't texted my coworker in like four days and i felt this weird guilt about it. like i'm already losing the connection thing.

also my mom called earlier today and we had like a normal conversation? nothing deep, just checking in. but instead of feeling relieved when we hung up i felt kind of... empty? like i was waiting for something that didn't happen. don't know if that makes sense.

sleep's still okay mostly but last night i couldn't fall asleep til late and i was just lying there spiraling about whether i'm doing any of this right. like am i making progress or just white-knuckling through some version of being "better" that isn't actually me.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work momentum and the guilt:**

Work's moving fast, you're actually into the new feature—that's the engaged-brain feeling you were missing when things were quiet. But then you noticed you haven't texted your coworker in four days and felt guilty, like you're already losing the connection thing. 

Here's what I want to name: not texting someone for four days isn't losing connection. Connection isn't measured by constant contact—it's measured by whether the relationship still feels alive when you do reach out. You had an easy lunch, you texted naturally for a bit, and now there's been a gap because work picked up. That's normal friendship rhythm, not abandonment.

The guilt might be coming from this idea that if you're not actively maintaining something, you're failing at it. But relationships aren't houseplants that die if you forget to water them for a few days. If you want to text your coworker, text them. If you don't, that's fine too. The connection you built doesn't evaporate because you got busy.

**The call with your mom—empty instead of relieved:**

You had a normal conversation with your mom—nothing deep, just checking in—and when you hung up you felt empty instead of relieved. Like you were waiting for something that didn't happen.

That empty feeling makes sense to me. The last call you had with her, you showed up vulnerably (told her about work stress, about trying to be more present), and she met you there. It felt different. This time it was just... normal. Surface-level. And I think part of you was hoping for that deeper connection again, and when it didn't happen, it left you feeling like something was missing.

Here's the thing: not every conversation has to be deep. Sometimes "normal" is fine. But if you're noticing that you wanted more and didn't get it, that tells me something shifted in you. You're not just protecting yourself and getting through calls anymore—you actually want real connection with her. And that want is going to feel uncomfortable sometimes when it doesn't get met.

One thing to consider: you can initiate depth, not just wait for it. If you want a real conversation, you can offer something real like you did last time. Not every call, but when you actually want it. You don't have to wait for her to go there first.

**Late-night spiral about whether you're doing it right:**

Sleep's been okay mostly, but last night you couldn't fall asleep and just lay there spiraling: am I making progress or just white-knuckling through some version of being "better" that isn't actually me?

This question hits at something real. Because there's a difference between genuinely changing and just performing change—doing the "right" things because you think you're supposed to, not because they actually fit who you are. And late at night when your brain won't shut off, that distinction feels impossible to see clearly.

Here's what I notice: you called your mom without overthinking it. You tried the cold water thing when you got snappy and it helped. You had an easy conversation with your coworker. None of that sounds like white-knuckling to me—it sounds like you experimenting with new ways of showing up and finding out what works. White-knuckling is forcing yourself to do things that feel wrong the whole time. What you're describing is more like: trying things, noticing how they feel, adjusting.

But I also hear the underneath question, which is: what if I'm just trying to be some version of "better" that isn't me? What if this whole thing is just me trying to fix myself into someone I'm not?

So let me ask you this: when you think about the changes you've been making—engaging more with your mom, noticing shutdown patterns, staying present with your coworker—does any of that feel like you're betraying who you actually are? Or does it feel more like you're learning to do things you actually want to do, just in ways you didn't know how to before?

exchanges.user:
So i've been thinking about what you said about white-knuckling versus actually wanting to do these things. and like... i think you're right that i'm not forcing myself through stuff that feels wrong. it actually does feel different when i engage with my mom versus when i'm just shutting down. but the spiral didn't really stop, you know?

Got home from work yesterday and just felt this heaviness. didn't even want to text my coworker back (she'd messaged me about grabbing coffee). just kinda sat with it for a while. Eventually i did respond but i was pretty distant about it. told her i was busy this week.

Which is true, work is busy. But also i'm wondering if i'm just retreating again when things feel messy. Like maybe the empty feeling from the mom call spooked me or something, and now i'm pulling back from everyone. Don't know. Hard to tell from inside it.

Sleep's been rough again. Last two nights i couldn't get comfortable, kept waking up. Not the spiraling thing, just like my body won't cooperate. Getting frustrated with myself about it which probably doesn't help.

Anyway. Is it normal to feel worse sometimes when you're supposedly making progress? Because that's what this feels like.
exchanges.assistant:
**The heaviness and pulling back:**

You got home yesterday and just felt heavy. Didn't want to text your coworker back about coffee, sat with it for a while, eventually responded but kept it distant—told her you were busy. And now you're wondering if you're retreating again, if the empty feeling from your mom's call spooked you into pulling back from everyone.

I think you're seeing it clearly. Something shifted after that call with your mom—you wanted depth, didn't get it, felt empty—and that disappointment or vulnerability or whatever it was seems to have triggered a retreat response. Not a dramatic shutdown, just a quiet pulling back. Telling your coworker you're busy when the truth is more like "I don't have it in me right now."

Here's what I want to say about that: retreating isn't always a problem. Sometimes it's your system saying "I need space to process" or "I don't have bandwidth right now." The question isn't whether you retreat—it's whether the retreat is protective in a healthy way, or whether it's you disappearing on yourself and everyone else because feelings got uncomfortable.

It sounds like you're worried it's the second one. That the messiness of wanting connection with your mom and not getting it scared you, so now you're preemptively protecting yourself from that disappointment happening again with your coworker or anyone else. If that's what's happening, it makes sense—but it also means you're letting one disappointing call with your mom dictate how you show up everywhere else. And that's worth noticing.

One thing you could try: instead of telling your coworker you're busy when you're really just not up for it, what if you said something closer to the truth? Not a feelings dump, just: "I'm kinda in my head this week, but let's do coffee next week?" That's still a boundary, but it's not a wall. It keeps the door open instead of shutting it.

**Sleep's rough again:**

Last two nights you couldn't get comfortable, kept waking up—not spiraling, just your body won't cooperate. And now you're frustrated with yourself about it, which probably makes it worse.

Yeah, the frustration definitely doesn't help. When sleep gets disrupted again after it's been stable, it's easy to spiral into "what am I doing wrong?" But sometimes sleep disruption is just your body responding to stress or emotional processing, not a sign you're failing at something. You've been doing hard emotional work—noticing patterns with your mom, sitting with emptiness and heaviness, questioning whether you're retreating—that takes a toll even when it's good work.

Your body might just need to discharge some of that. If the sleep thing continues, one option: try some movement during the day. Doesn't have to be a workout—just a 15-minute walk or stretching when you get home. Sometimes when emotional intensity has nowhere to go, it gets stuck in your body and disrupts sleep. Movement gives it a way out.

**Is it normal to feel worse when you're making progress?**

Yes. Absolutely yes.

Here's why: when you start noticing patterns and engaging differently, you're not just adding new skills—you're also feeling things you've been avoiding. The shutdown with your mom wasn't just about being tired or overwhelmed; it was protecting you from disappointment, from wanting things you might not get, from the risk of being real and not having it land. Now you're engaging more, and guess what? You're feeling that disappointment. You're feeling the emptiness when a call doesn't go deep. You're feeling the heaviness when you don't know if you're retreating or just resting.

That's not you getting worse—that's you feeling more. And feeling more can suck, especially at first, because you're not numb anymore. You're awake to what's actually happening, and some of what's happening is uncomfortable.

Progress isn't linear, and it's definitely not "I feel better every week." Sometimes progress looks like: I'm aware of my patterns now, and that awareness makes me feel worse before it makes me feel better. You're in that phase. It doesn't mean you're doing it wrong—it means you're doing it, and it's hard.

exchanges.user:

exchanges.assistant:
**Work feeling like noise:**

A couple weeks ago your brain needed something to focus on, and now that you have it, it's just... meh. All noise.
